definitions: teach a person or animal particular skills or behavior through practice
prepare physically for a sporting event through exercise and practice
point or aim something such as a gun or camera at a target
examples: We train new employees for two weeks
She trains guide dogs for the blind
Athletes train hard for the Olympics
He trains at the gym every morning
The soldier trained his rifle on the target
She trained the telescope on distant stars

definitions: connect or join physically or electronically with something else
show or suggest a connection or relationship between two things
examples: Evidence links smoking to lung cancer
Police linked him to the crime

definitions: have or show qualities worthy of reward or punishment through one's actions
examples: She deserves recognition for her hard work

definitions: establish the truth or correctness of something previously believed or suspected
make a booking or arrangement definite and certain
examples: Can you confirm receipt of the email
Please confirm your reservation by Friday

definitions: demand something forcefully not accepting refusal or opposition
state something firmly and repeatedly especially when challenged or opposed
examples: She insisted on paying for dinner
I insist that you see a doctor
They insist the story is true

definitions: make forceful efforts to get free of restraint or constriction
have difficulty handling or coping with something challenging
examples: The prisoner struggled against his chains

definitions: become or make larger or more extensive in size or scope
give more details or develop something already mentioned
examples: The company plans to expand internationally
Could you expand on that point

definitions: send a missile ship or spacecraft on its course or into space
start or introduce a new product enterprise or campaign
examples: NASA will launch the rocket tomorrow
They launched the boat at dawn
The company launches its new product next month

definitions: do something again or more than once in the same way
say something again often for emphasis or clarity
push something firmly against something else with steady force
make strong efforts to persuade or force someone to do something
examples: She pressed her face against the window
Don't press me for a decision

definitions: produce or create something especially when it involves a process
examples: The discussion generated many new ideas

definitions: continue for a specified period of time without stopping
be sufficient or adequate for a particular period or purpose
examples: How long will this rain last
This food should last us a week
My patience won't last much longer

definitions: like one thing or person better than another or others
aim something in a particular direction or at a target
control the operations of or manage an organization or activity
give authoritative instructions to someone about what to do
examples: Direct the light toward the stage
She directed her comments at me
She directed us to our seats

definitions: set down in writing or other permanent form for later reference
capture sound or moving images using electronic equipment for reproduction
examples: Record all expenses in this ledger
They recorded their first album last year
The camera records in high definition

definitions: take someone prisoner especially in war or by force
record accurately in words or images the essence of something
attract and hold the interest or attention of someone
examples: The photo captures the mood perfectly

definitions: carefully choose someone or something as being the best or most suitable
examples: Select the best candidate for the job
She selected a dress for the party

definitions: place documents or information in a particular order for storage
submit a legal document application or formal request officially
smooth or shape something using a tool with a rough surface
examples: He filed a complaint with the board
File your nails after cutting them
The prisoner filed through the bars

definitions: legally take another's child and bring up as one's own
choose to take up follow or use a new approach or course
examples: They decided to adopt a baby
We should adopt a different strategy

definitions: find an answer to or explanation for a problem or mystery
examples: Police are trying to solve the case

definitions: give financial material or moral support to a person or organization
move backward or cause something to move away from a direction
examples: I'll back you whatever you decide
Back the car into the garage
She backed away from the door

definitions: cease to be visible or stop being in a particular place suddenly
cease to exist or be in use gradually or suddenly
examples: The magician made the rabbit disappear

definitions: say or estimate that something will happen in the future based on evidence
examples: Can anyone predict the weather accurately

definitions: supply or distribute something officially to people who need it
come go or flow out from a source or origin
examples: The school issues textbooks to students

definitions: make something free from dirt marks or mess by washing or wiping
make something morally pure or free from corruption
examples: Clean your room before guests arrive
We need to clean up corruption

definitions: carry out a systematic inquiry to discover facts about something
examples: Scientists investigate the causes of disease

definitions: be afraid of someone or something as likely to be dangerous
be anxious or worried that something bad might happen
have enough money to pay for something without difficulty
provide or supply an opportunity or facility naturally
examples: We can't afford a new car

definitions: accept or admit the existence or truth of something
express gratitude or appreciation for something done
examples: The author acknowledged her editor's help

definitions: discover the exact place or position of something or someone
establish something in a particular place or position
examples: Can you locate the restaurant on the map
They plan to locate their office downtown
The company located its factory near the port

definitions: be in or move into a sloping position from vertical
depend on or trust in someone or something for support
examples: Don't lean against the wet paint
The tower leans to one side
She leans on her family for help

definitions: gain a point goal or run in a competitive game or sport
mark with lines or cuts especially to create a pattern
remove obstructions unwanted items or people from an area
make something easy to understand by explaining it well
become transparent bright or free of cloud or mist
examples: Let me clear up this confusion
I'll clear this with my boss
The sky cleared after the storm
Wait for the water to clear

definitions: carry the weight of or support something heavy physically
endure an ordeal or difficult situation with patience
give birth to a child or young animal
examples: The bridge can bear heavy loads

definitions: examine or assess something formally with the intention of change
write a critical assessment of a book play or movie
examples: The committee will review all applications
She reviews books for the newspaper

definitions: dispute the truth or validity of something with authority
test the abilities of someone in a demanding way
examples: He challenged their decision in court
This puzzle will challenge your mind
The job challenges her every day

definitions: give or allow someone something formally or legally
admit that something is true although reluctantly
examples: They granted him permission to leave
I grant that you have a point

definitions: announce something clearly firmly and publicly in an official way
state or assert something emphatically or publicly
examples: The president declared a state of emergency
She declared her love for him

definitions: arrange things into a structured order or system
form people into a group to work together effectively
examples: She organized the files by date

definitions: be all around someone or something on all sides enclosing them
put forward an idea or plan for consideration or discussion
make an offer of marriage to someone
examples: I propose we take a different approach
When will you propose to her

definitions: depend on with full trust or confidence for support or help
make a visible sign or stain on something
indicate the position or location of something
assess and give a grade to academic work
examples: Don't mark the walls with crayons
The accident marked him for life
Mark your place in the book

definitions: assume that something is true without having proof
be expected or required to do something by rules or expectations
examples: You're supposed to arrive by nine
What am I supposed to do

definitions: mark a special occasion or event with festivities or rejoicing
praise or honor someone or something publicly
seize someone by legal authority and take into custody
stop or check the progress or movement of something
move rhythmically to music typically following a set sequence of steps
examples: She loves to dance at parties

definitions: cause trouble worry or annoyance to someone persistently
take the trouble to do something when it requires effort
examples: Don't bother me while I'm working

definitions: move or cause to move from one place or position to another
change gear in a vehicle to control speed
examples: Shift your weight to the left

definitions: inform someone in advance of possible danger problem or unpleasant situation
examples: I warned you about the ice
